items.title: ‘First phase’ of ceasefire deal to end war in Gaza agreed by Israel and Hamas
items.standfirst: Donald Trump announces that all hostages will be released ‘very soon’ and Israel will withdraw troops to an agreed upon lineFollow the latest updates liveIsrael and Hamas have agreed to the initial phase of a “peace plan” in Gaza, pausing hostilities in the devastated territory and bringing the best hope yet of a definitive end to a bloody two-year conflict that has killed ten of thousands, destabilised much of the Middle East and prompted protests across the world.Donald Trump announced the agreement on his Truth Social network saying all of the hostages held in Gaza would be released soon and Israel would withdraw troops to an agreed upon line as the first step to a “Strong, Durable, and Everlasting Peace”. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump says Israel and Hamas have agreed first phase of Gaza peace plan

items.content: US president says all hostages to be released ‘very soon’ as he hails breakthrough deal

items.title: Thursday briefing: What the first phase of a Gaza peace plan will bring
items.standfirst: In today’s newsletter: A ceasefire between Israel and Hamas will see the release of hostages and the withdrawal of most of Israel’s troopsGood morning. After more than two years of devastating war, a ceasefire has finally been announced in Gaza.US president Donald Trump said Israel and Hamas have agreed to the first phase of a peace plan to pause fighting and secure the release of hostages and prisoners. Under the deal, Hamas is expected to release 20 surviving hostages over the coming days in exchange for Palestinian detainees, while Israeli forces will begin withdrawing from most of Gaza.Gaza | Israel and Hamas have agreed to the “first phase” of a peace plan to pause fighting and release some hostages and prisoners held in Gaza, bringing the best hope yet of a definitive end to a bloody two-year conflict that has killed ten of thousands, destabilised much of the Middle East and prompted protests across the world.Health | Ministers are preparing to raise the amount the NHS pays pharmaceutical firms for medicines by up to 25% after weeks of intensive talks with the Donald Trump administration and drugmakers.Education | Universities in the UK reassured arms companies they would monitor students’ chat groups and social media accounts after firms raised concerns about campus protests, according to internal emails.AI | The Bank of England has warned there is a growing risk of a “sudden correction” in global markets as it raised concerns about soaring valuations of leading AI tech companies.Politics | The Conservatives will scrap stamp duty on sales of primary residences if they win the next election, Kemi Badenoch has said, in a policy-heavy speech designed to improve her standing as Tory leader and her party’s economic credibility with voters. Continue reading...
items.content: In today’s newsletter: A ceasefire between Israel and Hamas will see the release of hostages and the withdrawal of most of Israel’s troopsGood morning. After more than two years of devastating war, a ceasefire has finally been announced in Gaza.US president Donald Trump said Israel and Hamas have agreed to the first phase of a peace plan to pause fighting and secure the release of hostages and prisoners. Under the deal, Hamas is expected to release 20 surviving hostages over the coming days in exchange for Palestinian detainees, while Israeli forces will begin withdrawing from most of Gaza.Gaza | Israel and Hamas have agreed to the “first phase” of a peace plan to pause fighting and release some hostages and prisoners held in Gaza, bringing the best hope yet of a definitive end to a bloody two-year conflict that has killed ten of thousands, destabilised much of the Middle East and prompted protests across the world.Health | Ministers are preparing to raise the amount the NHS pays pharmaceutical firms for medicines by up to 25% after weeks of intensive talks with the Donald Trump administration and drugmakers.Education | Universities in the UK reassured arms companies they would monitor students’ chat groups and social media accounts after firms raised concerns about campus protests, according to internal emails.AI | The Bank of England has warned there is a growing risk of a “sudden correction” in global markets as it raised concerns about soaring valuations of leading AI tech companies.Politics | The Conservatives will scrap stamp duty on sales of primary residences if they win the next election, Kemi Badenoch has said, in a policy-heavy speech designed to improve her standing as Tory leader and her party’s economic credibility with voters. Continue reading...

items.title: Prisoner-hostage swap, aid surge: What we know about the new Gaza deal
items.standfirst: The first phase of the Gaza peace plan, which is set to be signed Thursday in Egypt, entails the release of 20 living Israeli hostages from Hamas captivity while Israel will release nearly 2,000 Palestinian prisoners, most of whom were detained at the start of the war, according to sources. Here are more details on the latest US-backed Gaza ceasefire deal.

items.title: Israel and Hamas agree to first phase of peace plan, Trump says
items.standfirst: Israel and Hamas have struck a deal for Hamas to release all remaining hostages and for Israel to withdraw its forces to an "agreed upon line," President Trump announced, calling it the "first phase" of a peace deal to end the two-year-long war. Ed O'Keefe and Debora Patta have more.

Ed O'Keefe and Debora Patta have more.

items.title: Live: Israel, Hamas agreement on Gaza deal expected at noon local time
items.standfirst: Israel and Hamas have agreed to the first phase of a US-proposed Gaza deal, allowing for the release of all Israeli hostages, said President Donald Trump. The agreement, to be signed Thursday at noon local time (11am Paris time), also calls for Israel to release hundreds of Palestinian prisoners as well as prompt a surge of aid into the besieged enclave. Follow our liveblog for all the latest developments.
items.content: Israel and Hamas have agreed to the first phase of a US-proposed Gaza deal, allowing for the release of all Israeli hostages, said President Donald Trump. The agreement, to be signed Thursday at noon local time (11am Paris time), also calls for Israel to release hundreds of Palestinian prisoners as well as prompt a surge of aid into the besieged enclave. Follow our liveblog for all the latest developments.

items.title: France’s Macron to appoint new prime minister within 48 hours
items.standfirst: The announcement came after last-ditch talks by outgoing premier Sebastien Lecornu failed to find a solution to crisis.
items.content: The announcement came after last-ditch talks by outgoing premier Sebastien Lecornu failed to find a solution to crisis.

items.title: Outgoing French PM says will present draft budget next Monday
items.standfirst: France's caretaker Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu said he'd present a draft bill next Monday, adding that there was "a lot to debate" on the bill. Among the sticking points is President Emmanuel Macron's signature pension reform passed in 2023. So could it possibly be suspended? If so, at what cost? Also in the segment, as the price of gold surges past $4,000/oz, we take a look at the reasons behind the record rally.
items.content: France's caretaker Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu said he'd present a draft bill next Monday, adding that there was "a lot to debate" on the bill. Among the sticking points is President Emmanuel Macron's signature pension reform passed in 2023. So could it possibly be suspended? If so, at what cost? Also in the segment, as the price of gold surges past $4,000/oz, we take a look at the reasons behind the record rally.

items.title: Macron will nominate new French prime minister in 48 hours

items.content: Sébastien Lecornu, the outgoing prime minister, said MPs recognise the pressing need to pass a budget by the end of the year.

items.title: Outgoing French PM says ‘path still exists’ to avoid snap elections
items.standfirst: Sébastien Lecornu says majority of MPs willing to seek agreement on budget and avoid further instabilityFrance’s caretaker prime minister, Sébastien Lecornu, has said a majority of MPs “rejects the idea” of snap elections and that “a path still exists” that should allow Emmanuel Macron to appoint a new premier within 48 hours.“Several groups are willing to seek agreement on a budget” for 2026, Lecornu told France 2 public television on Wednesday, and were making clear their “conditions”. Talks would be difficult, he said, but “the prospect of a dissolution [of parliament] is fading”. Continue reading...
items.content: Sébastien Lecornu says majority of MPs willing to seek agreement on budget and avoid further instabilityFrance’s caretaker prime minister, Sébastien Lecornu, has said a majority of MPs “rejects the idea” of snap elections and that “a path still exists” that should allow Emmanuel Macron to appoint a new premier within 48 hours.“Several groups are willing to seek agreement on a budget” for 2026, Lecornu told France 2 public television on Wednesday, and were making clear their “conditions”. Talks would be difficult, he said, but “the prospect of a dissolution [of parliament] is fading”. Continue reading...

ai_summary: French President Macron will nominate a new prime minister soon.
Outgoing Prime Minister Lecornu said MPs recognize the need to pass a budget.
Lecornu stated a majority of MPs reject snap elections.
Talks on the budget will be difficult, according to Lecornu.
The prospect of dissolving parliament is fading, Lecornu said.

items.title: Former FBI head James Comey pleads not guilty in Justice Department case pushed by Trump
items.standfirst: Former FBI director James Comey pleaded not guilty on Wednesday to criminal charges accusing him of making false statements to Congress and obstructing a congressional investigation, in the first prosecution by the Justice Departmant against one of US President Donald Trump's political foes. Comey faces up to five years in prison if he is convicted.
items.content: Former FBI director James Comey pleaded not guilty on Wednesday to criminal charges accusing him of making false statements to Congress and obstructing a congressional investigation, in the first prosecution by the Justice Departmant against one of US President Donald Trump's political foes. Comey faces up to five years in prison if he is convicted.

ai_summary: Former FBI Director James Comey pleaded not guilty to charges.
Comey is accused of making false statements to Congress.
He is also accused of obstructing a congressional investigation.
The trial is scheduled for January 5.
Comey's legal team argues the case is politically motivated.

items.title: Why the government shutdown is playing into travel delays
items.standfirst: Earlier this week, Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy said one of the reasons for staffing shortages at airports is that a growing number of air traffic controllers have been calling out sick. Those controllers don't know when they'll get their next paycheck amid the government shutdown. CBS News correspondent Nicole Valdes has more.
items.content: Earlier this week, Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy said one of the reasons for staffing shortages at airports is that a growing number of air traffic controllers have been calling out sick. items.title: Man charged with starting Palisades fire that killed 12 people
items.standfirst: Jonathan Rinderknecht allegedly started blaze that destroyed over 6,800 structures in CaliforniaA 29-year-old man has been arrested and charged with igniting the fire that days later became the devastating Palisades blaze, which killed 12 people and destroyed more than 6,800 structures in one of the most destructive wildfires in Los Angeles history.Jonathan Rinderknecht was arrested near his Florida residence on federal charges of destruction of property by means of fire, acting US attorney for the central district of California, Bill Essayli, announced on Wednesday. No motive was presented. Continue reading...
items.content: Jonathan Rinderknecht allegedly started blaze that destroyed over 6,800 structures in CaliforniaA 29-year-old man has been arrested and charged with igniting the fire that days later became the devastating Palisades blaze, which killed 12 people and destroyed more than 6,800 structures in one of the most destructive wildfires in Los Angeles history.Jonathan Rinderknecht was arrested near his Florida residence on federal charges of destruction of property by means of fire, acting US attorney for the central district of California, Bill Essayli, announced on Wednesday. No motive was presented. Continue reading...

items.title: Man arrested over deadly January fire in Los Angeles
items.standfirst: Authorities investigating the deadly Palisades Fire that tore through an affluent Los Angeles suburb in January said Wednesday they had arrested a man who they believe started the blaze. Jonathan Rinderknecht, 29, was taken into custody in Florida, on suspicion of destruction of property by means of fire, Acting United States Attorney Bill Essayli said. FRANCE 24's Wassim Cornet reports from Los Angeles.
items.content: Authorities investigating the deadly Palisades Fire that tore through an affluent Los Angeles suburb in January said Wednesday they had arrested a man who they believe started the blaze. Jonathan Rinderknecht, 29, was taken into custody in Florida, on suspicion of destruction of property by means of fire, Acting United States Attorney Bill Essayli said. FRANCE 24's Wassim Cornet reports from Los Angeles.

items.title: UK synagogue attacker pledged allegiance to Islamic State group during rampage, police say
items.standfirst: Jihad al-Shamie, the man who was shot dead by police during a deadly rampage at a synagogue in England's northwest last week, reportedly claimed he had pledged allegiance to the Islamic State group in a phone call to police during the attack, counter terrorism police said Wednesday. Two people were killed in the attack, one accidentally shot by police as he barricaded the place of worship.
items.content: Jihad al-Shamie, the man who was shot dead by police during a deadly rampage at a synagogue in England's northwest last week, reportedly claimed he had pledged allegiance to the Islamic State group in a phone call to police during the attack, counter terrorism police said Wednesday. Two people were killed in the attack, one accidentally shot by police as he barricaded the place of worship.

items.title: Manchester synagogue attacker claimed allegiance to ISIS, UK police say
items.standfirst: Police said Jihad al-Shamie called emergency services to declare allegiance to armed group as he carried out the attack.
items.content: Police said Jihad al-Shamie called emergency services to declare allegiance to armed group as he carried out the attack.

ai_summary: Jihad al-Shamie claimed allegiance to the Islamic State group during the attack.
He made the claim in a phone call to emergency services during the rampage.
The attacker was shot dead by police during the incident.
Two people were killed in the attack, one by police.
The attack occurred at a synagogue in England's northwest.

clusters.title: Somalia embraces Swahili to strengthen East African Community ties
clusters.neutral_headline: Somalia Adopts Swahili to Strengthen East African Community Ties
bullet_summary: Reported by Al Jazeera, BBC World

items.title: Somalia embraces Swahili to strengthen East African Community ties
items.standfirst: President Mohamud says adopting Swahili 'important for our integration into the region'.
items.content: President Mohamud says adopting Swahili 'important for our integration into the region'.

items.title: Somalia to increase Swahili teaching to boost East African ties
items.standfirst: The president says it will speed up integration into East Africa, seen as crucial for boosting trade.
items.content: The president says it will speed up integration into East Africa, seen as crucial for boosting trade.

ai_summary: Somalia plans to adopt Swahili to boost integration in East Africa.
President Mohamud said Swahili adoption is important for integration.
The move is seen as crucial for boosting trade in the region.
Somalia aims to increase Swahili teaching in the country.
The president believes it will speed up integration into the region.
